Jobseekers, this one’s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up… the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn’t about you or your skills. It’s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn’t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. 🌻
Kutafuta kazi kwenye LinkedIn ni kama kuchumbiana mtandaoni: Ahadi nyingi, lakini mwisho wa siku, umeachwa tu bila majibu.

Ulaghai wa LinkedIn uko hivi: 'Hongera, umechaguliwa kwa nafasi ambayo hata hukuomba!' 
 Lakini sharti ulipe Sh. 50,000 kwa heshima hiyo.

Kuota ndoto ni jambo zuri,
lakini kuota ndoto ya kazi na kuandika 'nimevutiwa',
hiyo siyo jambo zuri, sivyo?

Mara nyingine nikisoma hadithi ya Influencer wa LinkedIn, nitaanza na mstari wa mwisho.
Kama kuna kiungo kimeambatanishwa, labda ni feki.
Naokoa muda wangu!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn’t nothing. It was the Universe’s way of saying, “Not this one, something better is on the way.”

Every single time, I’ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don’t go as planned, I don’t panic.

I don’t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can’t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company’s brand name doesn’t define someone’s talent. It’s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I’ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don’t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too—people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let’s stop attaching someone’s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this—skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don’t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

So when I left a toxic work environment, I told my manager a simple thing and felt so good 😯

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.
Thank you.'

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

I just told her that I wish her son would get a manager like she was.

If you felt bad, then that means you were a bad manager and now you know it. 🧐

If you feel good, then take it as a blessing for your son and you'll really want someone to treat your son/daughter in the same way.

She cannot be even angry with me else it'll prove that she was not a 'great' manager.

Muskan - 1
Manager - 0

Muskan -> Aura +100000000

(Fictional message unfortunately :(
)

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under 🙏

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)

I once asked a hiring manager for feedback after getting rejected.

She replied:

'You did great, we just went ahead with someone more experienced.'

A week later, the job was reposted.

No new description. No changes. Just posted again.

That’s when I realized:

Sometimes it's not your experience.
Sometimes it’s not your resume.

Sometimes it’s just that they weren’t ready for someone like you.

Don't let one company's silence make you question your worth. You're not everyone's cup of tea, but you're definitely someone's perfect blend. ☕️
If job hunting were a video game, ghosting would be the final boss.

The hardest part of being unemployed isn’t the lack of money.
It’s explaining to your relatives that job searching is a full-time job too.

'We’re looking for someone with 5 years of experience in a technology launched last year.'

Recruiters, please. Be serious.

You know what takes courage?

Writing that 'Thank you for the opportunity' email right after your confidence got shattered by an interview panel.

Applying to jobs feels like screaming into the void.

Except the void occasionally replies with:

‘We regret to inform you…’

Every LinkedIn success story starts with 'I’m thrilled to announce…'

But behind the scenes, it’s more like:

‘I cried 3 nights straight, got rejected 12 times, and doubted myself daily.’

Let’s normalize sharing the *real* journey too.

Had 6 interviews with one company.
Thought I was in.

They ghosted.

No rejection, no explanation.

Just silence.

It’s been 2 months.

Sometimes closure is knowing *you showed up*, even when they didn’t.

When a recruiter says, 'We’ll keep your resume on file,'

That file is called: Recycle Bin.

Job interviews should have reverse feedback.

Like: 'Dear company, after much consideration, I've decided not to proceed due to vague JD, unclear expectations, and the ghosting I sensed in your tone.'

One day, you’re going to look back at this phase and realize: 

You didn’t give up when it was the hardest.

You were tired, anxious, uncertain — but still showing up, still applying, still hoping.

That strength? It’s your superpower.
